required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018

clinical_study.brief_title: Once Weekly Subcutaneous Ports for the Administration of Anticoagulants
clinical_study.official_title: Once Weekly Subcutaneous Ports for the Administration of Anticoagulants - A Prospective Pharmacokinetic and Clinical Utilization Study

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to ascertain whether subcutaneous ports are an effective and reliable way to administer the low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) enoxaparin to patients for the prevention or treatment of venous thromboembolism.

detailed_description.textblock:
Subcutaneous ports have recently been used to administer Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) to patients for the prevention or treatment of venous thromboembolism; however, no studies have been performed to evaluate the ports' reliability in delivering this type of drug. Hence, it is not known whether absorption of the drug is constant over the seven-day lifespan of the port. Although the use of subcutaneous ports is not currently the standard of care, health care providers are more frequently using this as an alternative method to direct injection of LMWH, particularly in pediatric patients.
The main advantage of subcutaneous ports is the decreased number of needle sticks when using the ports to administer the medication. However, it is possible that, due to potential repeated bleeding into the subcutaneous space at the port site or other factors, drug absorption may decrease over the seven day lifespan of the port, resulting in a decrease of plasma drug level. Subtherapeutic LMWH levels and, hence, ineffective anticoagulation may result. This study's aim is to determine if the current use of subcutaneous ports is a safe, effective and reliable way of administering LMWH for the purpose of anticoagulation.

primary_outcome.description: Blood levels taken from the first and last visits (when available) were combined to get an average. The anti-Xa test reports the low molecular weight heparin concentration in the blood.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Difference of Each Participant's Subcutaneous Anti-Xa Levels
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 6 time points (for each participant) in approximately 3 months
secondary_outcome.description: Anti-Xa subcutaneous blood levels are displayed in percent difference to show normal fluctuations of anti-Xa levels without using the port. A percent difference is calculated by the current value has the previous value subtracted from it; this new number is divided by the absolute value of the previous value; then this new number is multiplied by 100. This allows each set of data to be compared to itself. Anti-Xa tests measure the concentration of low molecular weight heparin in the blood.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Difference of Each Participant's Anti-Xa Levels Without Port and Day One of Using the Port
secondary_outcome.description: Comparing subcutaneous baseline (without port) anti-Xa levels with day one of using the port. A percent difference is calculated by the current value has the previous value subtracted from it; this new number is divided by the absolute value of the previous value; then this new number is multiplied by 100. This allows each set of data to be compared to itself. Anti-Xa tests measure the concentration of low molecular weight heparin in the blood.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Difference of Each Participant's Anti-Xa Blood Levels Between Day 1 and Day 7
secondary_outcome.description: Comparing anti-Xa levels from the first day of using the port and the last day of using the port. A percent difference is calculated by the current value has the previous value subtracted from it; this new number is divided by the absolute value of the previous value; then this new number is multiplied by 100. This allows each set of data to be compared to itself. Anti-Xa tests measure the concentration of low molecular weight heparin in the blood.

secondary_outcome.measure: Standard Deviation of Participant's Own Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR)
secondary_outcome.description: GFR was calculated from a creatinine blood level to establish a safe renal function that would validate anti-Xa levels. Low molecular weight heparin is primarily cleared from the body by the kidneys. Any condition that decreases kidney function can potentially decrease LMWH clearance, increasing its concentration in the blood and increasing the potential for excessive bleeding.

arm_group.description: All participants in the study will use the subcutaneous catheter twice for a period of one week each to inject the enoxaparin. For the remainder of the study the participants will inject subcutaneously.

intervention.description: Indwelling subcutaneous catheter indicated for subcutaneous infusion of medication by injection. Maximum lifespan: 7 days or 75 injections.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Subjects receiving once or twice daily dosing of therapeutic doses of subcutaneous Enoxaparin.
- Subject has been on the same dose of Enoxaparin for at least one week.
- Anticipated length of Enoxaparin treatment at least 4 weeks.
- Age â‰¥ 18 years.
- Subject demonstration of proper subcutaneous catheter care during one education session with the investigator.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Chronic renal insufficiency with glomerular filtration rate < 30 mL/min.
- Pregnancy
- Venous thromboembolism within the last 4 weeks.

overall_official.affiliation: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill School of Medicine Department of Medicine

facility.name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill School of Medicine; University of North Carolina Hospital, N.C. Memorial Hospital

clinical_study.keyword: once or twice daily dosing of subcutaneous enoxaparin

group.title: Insuflon
group.description: All participants in the study will use the subcutaneous catheter twice for a period of one week each to inject the enoxaparin. For the remainder of the study the participants will inject subcutaneously.

group.title: Insuflon
group.description: All participants in the study will use the subcutaneous catheter twice for a period of one week each to inject the enoxaparin. For the remainder of the study the participants will inject subcutaneously.

outcome.title: Percent Difference of Each Participant's Subcutaneous Anti-Xa Levels
outcome.description: Anti-Xa subcutaneous blood levels are displayed in percent difference to show normal fluctuations of anti-Xa levels without using the port. A percent difference is calculated by the current value has the previous value subtracted from it; this new number is divided by the absolute value of the previous value; then this new number is multiplied by 100. This allows each set of data to be compared to itself. Anti-Xa tests measure the concentration of low molecular weight heparin in the blood.
outcome.time_frame: 6 time points (for each participant) in approximately 3 months
outcome.population: All participants were represented with a baseline fluctuation in percent difference.

group.title: All Participants
group.description: Both dosing schedules, once and twice daily, all participants.

measure.title: Percent Difference of Each Participant's Subcutaneous Anti-Xa Levels
measure.description: Anti-Xa subcutaneous blood levels are displayed in percent difference to show normal fluctuations of anti-Xa levels without using the port. A percent difference is calculated by the current value has the previous value subtracted from it; this new number is divided by the absolute value of the previous value; then this new number is multiplied by 100. This allows each set of data to be compared to itself. Anti-Xa tests measure the concentration of low molecular weight heparin in the blood.
measure.population: All participants were represented with a baseline fluctuation in percent difference.

outcome.title: Percent Difference of Each Participant's Anti-Xa Levels Without Port and Day One of Using the Port
outcome.description: Comparing subcutaneous baseline (without port) anti-Xa levels with day one of using the port. A percent difference is calculated by the current value has the previous value subtracted from it; this new number is divided by the absolute value of the previous value; then this new number is multiplied by 100. This allows each set of data to be compared to itself. Anti-Xa tests measure the concentration of low molecular weight heparin in the blood.
outcome.population: Twenty participants, excluding one outlier of 97%.

group.title: All Participants
group.description: All participants on both dosing schedules, once and twice daily LMWH.

measure.title: Percent Difference of Each Participant's Anti-Xa Levels Without Port and Day One of Using the Port
measure.description: Comparing subcutaneous baseline (without port) anti-Xa levels with day one of using the port. A percent difference is calculated by the current value has the previous value subtracted from it; this new number is divided by the absolute value of the previous value; then this new number is multiplied by 100. This allows each set of data to be compared to itself. Anti-Xa tests measure the concentration of low molecular weight heparin in the blood.
measure.population: Twenty participants, excluding one outlier of 97%.

outcome.title: Percent Difference of Each Participant's Anti-Xa Blood Levels Between Day 1 and Day 7
outcome.description: Comparing anti-Xa levels from the first day of using the port and the last day of using the port. A percent difference is calculated by the current value has the previous value subtracted from it; this new number is divided by the absolute value of the previous value; then this new number is multiplied by 100. This allows each set of data to be compared to itself. Anti-Xa tests measure the concentration of low molecular weight heparin in the blood.
outcome.population: All participants, excluding two outliers of 97% and 150%

group.title: All Participants
group.description: All participants on both dosing schedules, once and twice daily.

measure.title: Percent Difference of Each Participant's Anti-Xa Blood Levels Between Day 1 and Day 7
measure.description: Comparing anti-Xa levels from the first day of using the port and the last day of using the port. A percent difference is calculated by the current value has the previous value subtracted from it; this new number is divided by the absolute value of the previous value; then this new number is multiplied by 100. This allows each set of data to be compared to itself. Anti-Xa tests measure the concentration of low molecular weight heparin in the blood.
measure.population: All participants, excluding two outliers of 97% and 150%

outcome.title: Average Subcutaneous Anti-Xa Blood Levels
outcome.description: Blood levels taken from the first and last visits (when available) were combined to get an average. The anti-Xa test reports the low molecular weight heparin concentration in the blood.
outcome.population: Participants were separated into the two dosing schedules, since the target anti-Xa level is different for the two different types of doses. The once daily dosing sub-group was analyzed for this primary outcome measure.

group.title: Once Daily Dosing
group.description: 10 participants were placed on an once daily dosing schedule in accordance with their physician approved, standard of care weight specific dosage.

measure.title: Average Subcutaneous Anti-Xa Blood Levels
measure.description: Blood levels taken from the first and last visits (when available) were combined to get an average. The anti-Xa test reports the low molecular weight heparin concentration in the blood.
measure.population: Participants were separated into the two dosing schedules, since the target anti-Xa level is different for the two different types of doses. The once daily dosing sub-group was analyzed for this primary outcome measure.

outcome.title: Standard Deviation of Participant's Own Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR)
outcome.description: GFR was calculated from a creatinine blood level to establish a safe renal function that would validate anti-Xa levels. Low molecular weight heparin is primarily cleared from the body by the kidneys. Any condition that decreases kidney function can potentially decrease LMWH clearance, increasing its concentration in the blood and increasing the potential for excessive bleeding.
outcome.population: Included all participants who had at lease one visit and one blood draw.

group.title: All Participants
group.description: All participants on both a daily and twice daily dosing schedule

measure.title: Standard Deviation of Participant's Own Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR)
measure.description: GFR was calculated from a creatinine blood level to establish a safe renal function that would validate anti-Xa levels. Low molecular weight heparin is primarily cleared from the body by the kidneys. Any condition that decreases kidney function can potentially decrease LMWH clearance, increasing its concentration in the blood and increasing the potential for excessive bleeding.
measure.population: Included all participants who had at lease one visit and one blood draw.

group.title: Insuflon
group.description: All participants in the study will use the subcutaneous catheter twice for a period of one week each to inject the enoxaparin. For the remainder of the study the participants will inject subcutaneously.

event.sub_title: Subject had a recurrent deep vein thrombosis
event.description: Recurrent blood clots are a risk for patients who have already had a clot. This event was not related to the study procedure.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
